Simply connect your Git repository, start the translation, and we'll handle the rest. Our AI-powered platform takes care of everything automatically.

Intelligent translations based on your application's context and business domain
Our AI-powered translation engine understands your application's context, ensuring accurate and meaningful translations that maintain the original intent of your content.
Serve your application with translations during development:
For complex applications with different contexts
Failed to load repositories. Please check your token permissions and try again.
Analyzes your code to understand the context of each string
Ensures consistent translations across your entire application
Automated quality checks for translation accuracy
Start translating your Angular application in minutes.
Connect with GitHub, GitLab, and Bitbucket repositories seamlessly
Translate your Angular applications with AI-powered context-aware translations
Automated XLIFF Translation for Angular Applications
to extract and update all translation files in one step
After adding new translatable content or modifying existing translations:
Add the @angular/localize package to your dependencies
Add "@angular/localize/init" to the polyfills array in angular.json
Add the following reference to your main.ts:
This command will make the following changes:
It will also add the extract-i18n configuration to angular.json:
Start by adding Angular's localization package to your project:
Note: We'll modify the outputPath later in the configuration to match our workflow.
No repositories found. Please check your token permissions.
To make your components ready for translation, you need to mark the text that should be translated. Angular provides two ways to do this:
Angular Documentation: Marking Text for Translation
Smart analysis of your XLIFF files with context extraction
Automated pull request creation with translated XLIFF files
Our platform supports the following XLIFF formats for maximum compatibility with Angular's internationalization system:
Use the i18n attribute in your templates to mark text for translation:
The @@prefix defines a custom ID for the translation. Using SNAKE_CASE is recommended for consistency.
XLIFF Translator has revolutionized our localization workflow. The context-aware translations are incredibly accurate.
John Doe - Tech Lead at GlobalTech
The automated Git integration saved us countless hours of manual work. Highly recommended!
To connect, generate a Personal Access Token with the following scopes:
Information about where and how the text is used in your application
A TransUnit is the fundamental building block of XLIFF files. It represents a single piece of text that needs to be translated, along with its metadata and context.
The original text in your application's source language
The current status of the translation (initial, translated, reviewed, etc.)
The translated text in the target language
Oops! The page you're looking for seems to have vanished into the void...
Please enter your email to confirm account deletion. This action cannot be undone.
Password must be at least 6 characters
Update the i18n configuration in angular.json:
We have sent you an email with a confirmation link. Please check your inbox and click on the link to verify your email address.

Your email has been verified. You can now use all features of the application.
Add configurations for each language in the build section:
Select a provider: Choose from GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket
Configure access: Create and provide the appropriate tokens
Save your configuration: Enter your token and save the connection
Before running a translation, you can estimate the scope and complexity of the task:
The exact number of translation units that need processing
How many credits will be required (1 translation unit = 1 credit)
Approximate time required (each translation unit takes 10-20 seconds to process)
Important: Large translation projects with hundreds of translation units can take significant time. Plan accordingly.
The estimation process helps you understand:
Select the repository you want to work with
Click on "Estimate" to analyze your XLIFF files

Configure the estimate options:Branch: Select the branch containing your XLIFF filesFile Pattern: By default "xlf" to search all XLIFF files. Use specific patterns like "ru.xlf" to target only Russian filesTranslation State: Choose which translation units to include (default is "new" to focus on untranslated content)
Review the estimate results showing the number of translation units to process
Then replace the standard extract-i18n configuration with ng-extract-i18n-merge:
buildTarget: Your application's build target name
outputPath: Directory where translation files will be stored
includeContext: Includes source file information in the XLIFF files
resetTranslationState: Marks all translations as needing review on changes
targetFiles: List of translation files to generate/update
Automatically extracts translatable strings from your application
Merges new translations with existing ones in a single step
For managing translation files, we'll use ng-extract-i18n-merge which simplifies the process of extracting and merging translations:
Identifies XLIFF files matching your pattern
Analyzes each translation unit and its context in the source code
Sends translation instructions to the AI engine with relevant context
Updates the XLIFF files with the translations
Creates a pull request with the changes (if configured)
After connecting to a Git provider:
Navigate to the provider's page where your repositories are listed
Browse and select the repository containing your Angular project with XLIFF files
Specify the branch to work with (default is usually the main branch)
Learn about advanced i18n features like pluralization and selection.
Official tool for extracting and merging i18n translations in a single step.
This workflow allows you to keep translations in your version control system and follow standard code review practices for translation updates.
Review the created pull request in your Git provider
Check the translated content for accuracy
Make any necessary adjustments directly in the XLIFF files
Merge the pull request to update your main codebase with the translations
Learn more about how to prepare your application for translation.
Create a dedicated branch for translations to keep them separate from feature development
Ensure your source code has clear context for translation units to improve AI translation quality
Use specific file patterns to target translations for one language at a time
Run translations regularly as you develop to avoid large batches of untranslated content
Always review AI-generated translations, especially for critical user-facing content
Running an AI-powered translation is a separate process from estimation:
Select the repository containing your XLIFF files
Click on "Translate" to begin the process

Configure the translation options:Branch: Select the source branchFile Pattern: Specify which XLIFF files to translateTranslation State: Select which translation units to process (e.g., "new", "needs-translation")Target State: Define the state to set for translated units (e.g., "translated", "final")
During the translation process, XLIFF Translator:
This simplified workflow ensures your translation files are always up-to-date with source content, making the internationalization process more efficient and error-free.
Create an App Password with repository:read and repository:write permissions.
To connect, generate a Personal Access Token with the following scopes:
Get your token here: Settings > Developer settings > Personal access tokens > Tokens (classic) > Generate new token
Create a Personal Access Token with api, read_repository, and write_repository scopes.
Before using XLIFF Translator, you need to configure your Angular application for internationalization.
You'll be prompted with the translation options modal as shown earlier in the "Selecting Repositories" section.
